ALDE welcomes the focus on price transparency and consumer choice, noting its consistency with their longstanding advocacy for market-driven solutions over perpetual regulation.  
ALDE proposes strengthening implementation oversight mechanisms to ensure structural reforms achieve their intended competitive effects, particularly monitoring local break-out adoption rates.  
ALDE endorses the calibrated reduction of wholesale price ceilings, recognizing this balances consumer protection with incentives for infrastructure investment in next-generation networks.

SD strongly advocates the progressive reduction of roaming charges as a critical step toward eliminating artificial market barriers within the EU's single market framework.  
SD applauds the inclusion of the 2016 review mechanism, ensuring continued pressure to achieve full alignment between domestic and roaming tariffs by the target date.  
SD proposes strengthening future digital market regulations by explicitly incorporating network neutrality principles to prevent discriminatory data service practices.  
SD emphasizes that the structural measures enabling separate roaming service contracts from 2014 will enhance consumer choice and market competition as intended.  
SD commends the regulation's immediate consumer benefits, aligning perfectly with their commitment to tangible European integration outcomes for citizens.

ECR supports the roaming price caps as a consumer benefit but advises amending the regulation's duration to include a review clause by 2018 to prevent long-term market distortion.  
ECR endorses the separation of domestic and roaming services but suggests enhancing competition by lowering barriers for new telecom entrants in Article 4.  
ECR welcomes reduced data costs as pro-consumer, aligning with single market principles, but proposes allowing voluntary operator agreements under Commission oversight.  
ECR approves eliminating roaming charges by 2015 but recommends prioritizing cross-border infrastructure investments to address coverage gaps.  
ECR acknowledges the necessity of price regulation but urges the industry to innovate cost-reduction strategies to avoid future regulatory intervention.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's consumer protections and SME network access as steps toward fairer market participation.  
GUE_NGL advises introducing binding provisions for unified model contracts to prevent fragmented national implementations.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly prohibit operators from offsetting roaming losses through inflated domestic call pricing.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the improved comprehensiveness of this text over prior frameworks while urging stricter safeguards against corporate monopolistic practices.  
GUE_NGL highlights the necessity of ongoing oversight to ensure competition benefits consumers rather than reinforcing telecom oligopolies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0402) concerning the codification of existing legislation under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at harmonizing internal market rules. It endorsed the Consultative Working Party’s conclusion that the proposal did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, instead consolidating unchanged provisions from prior acts into a single text without altering their legal substance. The resolution emphasized adherence to the recasting technique outlined in the 2001 Interinstitutional Agreement, ensuring transparency in legislative updates. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, incorporating recommendations from the Working Party, and noted the Council’s commitment to approve this position under Article 294(4) TFEU, finalizing the codification process to enhance legal clarity while preserving existing regulatory frameworks.

title: Rules for the participation and dissemination in Horizon 2020: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down  the rules for the participation and dissemination in Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020)
background: The European Union's Horizon 2020 framework (2014-2020) was developed to strengthen research competitiveness and address societal challenges, following the Europe 2020 strategy for smart growth. Pre-existing conditions included EU commitments to innovation-driven economic recovery, streamlining prior framework programmes, and ensuring cross-border research collaboration. The Parliament will discuss regulatory parameters governing participation requirements and knowledge-sharing mechanisms in EU research funding under the research and innovation policy area.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the EIT's catalytic role in bridging academic research and market applications through Knowledge Innovation Communities (KICs).  
EPP strongly endorses Horizon 2020’s simplified SME participation rules and 20% funding reservation for market-driven innovation activities.  
EPP strongly approves structural fund synergies enabling cross-regional innovation partnerships under the Regional Innovation Scheme framework.  
EPP proposes leveraging the 2016 midterm review to advocate expanded budgetary allocations for high-priority KICs in emerging technological fields.  
EPP emphasizes strict adherence to subsidiarity in ethically sensitive research domains per national competencies under Article 168 TFEU.

EFD slightly sanctions the Horizon 2020 participation rules but demands major revisions to Article 5 provisions on climate-related funding allocations, citing disproportionate focus on "societal challenges" that impose energy cost burdens on industries.  
EFD completely rejects mandatory renewable energy integration clauses in Annex 2, arguing they contradict competitiveness priorities by accelerating "industrial massacre" through forced decarbonization timelines.  
EFD requests amendment of Article 7 to eliminate SME reporting requirements exceeding 15 administrative hours/month, aligning with concerns about overregulation stifling innovation capacity.  
EFD rejects the issue's centralized fund distribution model in Article 12, insisting on binding quotas to prevent "brain drain" from newer EU states and ensure equitable access to innovation resources.  
EFD challenges the scientific basis for climate disaster mitigation priorities in Section 3.2, urging deletion of all references to "extreme weather preparedness" as ideologically driven policy overreach.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's failure to prioritize renewable energy investments over nuclear fusion research, fully againsting with their climate action mandates.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the dismantling of the Intelligent Energy Europe Programme's renewable components, which overlooks critical grassroots energy transition strategies.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the undemocratic blocking of amendments to prevent Horizon 2020 funds from financing illegal settlements, violating international law principles.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the competitiveness narrative that neglects solar industry support while maintaining disproportionate nuclear funding allocations.  
GREEN_EFA demands full implementation of EU settlement guidelines in research partnerships, citing the issue's dangerous loopholes for geopolitical conflicts.

ALDE strongly advocates the prioritization of SMEs through dedicated €3.2 billion funding and simplified access mechanisms, aligning perfectly with their commitment to innovation-driven economic growth.  
ALDE applauds the integration of structural funds with Horizon 2020’s objectives, enhancing regional specialization and smart development strategies as part of their cohesion policy priorities.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on open access policies and cross-sector collaboration across academia, research institutions, and industry, reflecting their advocacy for transparent knowledge-sharing ecosystems.  
ALDE proposes strengthening the new unit’s operational capacity to ensure seamless structural reforms, particularly for SME participation and innovation group synergies, without opposing the issue’s core framework.  
ALDE underscores the focus on gender equality and green transition initiatives, which directly advance their manifesto goals for inclusive and sustainable research ecosystems.

SD strongly approves Horizon 2020's alignment with EU strategic goals on innovation and global partnerships, perfectly reflecting SD's commitment to sustainable growth and research excellence.  
SD approves the framework's focus on reversing brain drain and achieving the 3% GDP R&D target, urging member states to prioritize national funding increases to close this critical gap.  
SD highlights the need to strengthen market application mechanisms, proposing enhanced SME collaboration programs to accelerate commercialization of research outcomes.  
SD endorses the administrative simplification and open access provisions, ensuring research accessibility while suggesting expanded multilingual dissemination formats for wider societal impact.  
SD applauds the inclusion of neglected regions in participation instruments, effectively advancing SD's cross-sectoral priorities for reducing innovation disparities across Europe.

ECR supports the focus on excellence in project funding and simplification of bureaucratic processes, advising strict adherence to merit-based allocation to maintain competitiveness  
ECR proposes amending ethical clauses to explicitly prohibit EU funding for embryonic stem cell research, citing moral objections and scientific alternatives such as umbilical cord or reprogrammed skin cells  
ECR highlights concerns about co-financing mechanisms potentially disadvantaging countries with lower national research investments, urging balanced implementation to prevent wealthier states disproportionately benefiting  
ECR advises ensuring transparency in funding calls and open access to results through binding provisions for all Horizon 2020 participants  
ECR emphasizes the need to prevent administrative barriers in excellence criteria, ensuring fair access for research institutions regardless of prior statistical rankings

GUE_NGL completely challenges the issue’s complicity in channeling EU funds to Israeli arms companies and institutions operating in illegal settlements, which directly enables human rights violations against Palestinians.  
GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of public-private partnerships and security research, which divert public resources from democratically accountable social and employment-focused initiatives.  
GUE_NGL condemns the inadequate budgetary allocations for crisis-response job creation, highlighting the issue’s failure to meet declared goals of addressing systemic unemployment.  
GUE_NGL opposes the residual funding for ethically contentious research areas, such as security-focused projects, which contradict principles of peace and social justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0810) concerning policies under Treaty provisions on industrial competitiveness, research, energy, and international cooperation (Articles 173, 183, and 188 TFEU). The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, emphasizing the need to align the proposal with strategic EU goals in innovation, sustainable growth, and global partnerships. It instructed the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if making substantial amendments, ensuring legislative transparency. Parliament also directed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national legislatures, reflecting procedural adherence while prioritizing substantive alignment with EU treaty objectives. The resolution incorporated inputs from parliamentary committees on Industry, Foreign Affairs, Development, and Budgets (report A7-0428/2012), underscoring cross-sectoral priorities.

title: Security of gas supply: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning measures to safeguard security of gas supply and repealing Directive 2004/67/EC
background: Repeated gas supply disruptions in 2005-2006 and 2008-2009 winters exposed EU vulnerabilities due to import dependency, fragmented infrastructure, and limited cross-border crisis coordination. Rising geopolitical risks and market integration challenges underscored systemic weaknesses in safeguarding energy security. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to strengthen gas supply resilience and solidarity mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the establishment of common infrastructure standards and reverse flow mechanisms as critical to achieving EU energy solidarity, aligning with their commitment to integrated markets.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of diversifying gas sources and interconnecting isolated regions like the Baltic States, reflecting their strategic priority to reduce geopolitical dependencies.  
EPP approves the inclusion of households and SMEs as "protected customers" under emergency protocols, ensuring citizen-centric crisis management as outlined in their social market principles.  
EPP proposes enhancing the Commission’s role in providing targeted infrastructure funding to eliminate supply bottlenecks in vulnerable Member States like Poland.  
EPP applauds the crisis response framework’s alignment with geopolitical risk assessments, advancing their manifesto goals for proactive energy security governance.

EFD supports the regulation's crisis prevention mechanisms but proposes amending Article 8 to accelerate LNG terminal development in the Mediterranean with binding capacity targets.  
EFD advises revising Annex II to designate the Nabucco pipeline as a Project of Common Interest, ensuring prioritized funding and implementation timelines.  
EFD emphasizes that unresolved definitions of protected customers in Section 3.1 require clarification through delegated acts involving national regulators.  
EFD endorses cross-border infrastructure provisions yet urges amending Article 12 to standardize EU-level cost-sharing formulas for reverse flow installations.  
EFD highlights the need to address N-1 infrastructure standards in Article 5 through regional risk assessments post-adoption.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally upholds the issue's prioritization of reverse flow capacity infrastructure, perfectly aligning with their commitment to resilient energy systems and cross-border solidarity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for enhanced north-south gas interconnections in Central Europe, recognizing this as critical to advancing energy security and decarbonization pathways.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally upholds the issue’s procedural emphasis on institutional coordination, effectively advancing their priority of EU-level energy governance and demand forecasting rigor.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of long-term building efficiency impacts into gas demand assessments, mirroring their manifesto goals for systemic energy transition planning.  
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s implicit recognition of shale gas market dynamics, urging continued alignment with their principles of evidence-based energy diversification.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on market completion and transparency as essential to reducing energy vulnerability across member states.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 7 to explicitly mandate dismantling protectionist barriers in bilateral gas contracts, aligning with free market principles.  
ALDE approves the crisis-level framework and infrastructure diversification focus, particularly endorsing Nabucco and storage capacity expansion as critical to supply resilience.  
ALDE highlights the need to formalize partnerships with supplier nations like Turkmenistan through dedicated TFEU Article 194 trade instruments, ensuring strategic diversification.  
ALDE commends the solidarity mechanism for emergency supply sharing as fully consistent with cross-border energy market integration goals.

SD fundamentally endorses the issue's emphasis on European solidarity through mandatory reverse-flow infrastructure and cross-border interconnection development, perfectly aligning with S&D's vision of collective energy security.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of vulnerable consumer protections as a regulatory cornerstone, reflecting their manifesto commitment to shield households from geopolitical supply shocks.  
SD fully supports the strategic diversification of supply routes via projects like Nabucco, viewing this as essential to breaking external monopolies while maintaining perfect coherence with their energy sovereignty principles.  
SD strongly advocates for the issue’s unified external energy policy framework, which operationalizes their long-standing demand for coordinated EU negotiations with supplier states like Russia.  
SD commends the integration of regional cooperation mechanisms into emergency protocols, seeing this as an exemplary implementation of Lisbon Treaty solidarity obligations central to S&D’s energy agenda.

ECR fully agrees the regulation as a critical safeguard against monopolistic market distortions, perfectly aligning with its commitment to competitive energy markets and consumer protection.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on infrastructure connectivity and crisis coordination mechanisms, recognizing their necessity for Central Europe’s sovereignty amid geopolitical energy threats.  
ECR applauds the compromise for advancing a unified energy policy, reflecting its prioritization of EU strategic autonomy against external supply manipulation.  
ECR underscores the importance of flexible crisis-response frameworks, aligning with its principles of subsidiarity and market efficiency to avoid excessive regulatory burdens.  
ECR highlights the geopolitical imperative of the regulation, reinforcing its stance that energy security is inseparable from broader EU independence and resilience.

GUE_NGL totally disapproves the issue's reliance on market mechanisms, which contradicts their demand for public ownership and democratic control of energy resources.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as nationalizing gas multinationals to sever corporate dominance, a core GUE_NGL principle for supply security.  
GUE_NGL rejects the absence of binding measures to remove energy from speculative markets, directly conflicting with their anti-capitalist energy governance model.  
This issue fails to address tariff agreements ensuring producer country sovereignty, undermining GUE_NGL's internationalist solidarity framework.  
The proposal ignores biomethane development as a non-fossil alternative, neglecting GUE_NGL's ecological transition priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2009 legislative proposal (COM(2009)0363), grounded in Treaty provisions including Article 251(2) and Article 95 of the EC Treaty, as well as Articles 294(3) and 194(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution incorporated input from the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and parliamentary committees on Industry, Research and Energy (leading), Foreign Affairs, Economic and Monetary Affairs, Environment, and Internal Market and Consumer Protection. It emphasized alignment with post-Lisbon Treaty procedures (COM(2009)0665) and legislative frameworks, adopting a substantive stance on the proposal while underscoring institutional coordination and adherence to EU legislative processes. The resolution did not specify numerical targets but focused on procedural continuity, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments.

title: Trans-European energy infrastructure: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure and repealing Decision No 1364/2006/EC
background: The EU's 2006 energy infrastructure framework faced challenges in cross-border connectivity, lengthy permitting, and regional energy isolation, hindering market integration and renewable energy transition amid rising energy security concerns. The Parliament will discuss a proposed regulation updating trans-European energy infrastructure guidelines to address these barriers and enhance interconnectivity.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the regulation’s prioritization of Central/Eastern European energy interconnectivity, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to reducing regional disparities in EU infrastructure.  
EPP approves the accelerated permitting framework for Projects of Common Interest, which effectively advances energy security goals while proposing enhanced monitoring of cross-border project consultations under Article 7(2).  
EPP endorses the Connecting Europe Facility’s role in funding strategic initiatives like Nabucco, perfectly matching EPP’s manifesto priorities for diversified energy partnerships with Caspian Basin states.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity to allocate 35% of CEF energy funds to Baltic and Black Sea interconnectors, addressing critical gaps while maintaining full alignment with the issue’s objectives.  
EPP proposes reinforcing ACER’s mandate to validate ENTSO cost-benefit analyses, ensuring socio-economic assessments reflect regional security needs without opposing the core approval mechanism.

GREEN_EFA totally conflicts the proposal's structural failure to mandate renewable-first grid modernization required for climate neutrality  
GREEN_EFA rejects the inadequate integration of financial instruments like project bonds critical for leveraging sustainable energy funding  
The issue dangerously overlooks binding timelines for phasing out fossil fuel infrastructure incompatible with Paris Agreement targets  
GREEN_EFA condemns the procedural neglect of regional smart grid solutions that empower local renewable energy communities  
This framework contradicts GREEN_EFA's decarbonization redlines by permitting continued gas infrastructure investments until 2050

ALDE strongly advocates the energy infrastructure guidelines as crucial for completing the single market and advancing EU competitiveness, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to integrated economic development.  
ALDE proposes strengthening the use of innovative financial instruments to offset budget cuts, urging amendments to Article 9 to expand leverage mechanisms for private-sector participation.  
ALDE approves the prioritization of cross-border projects but emphasizes enhancing strategic allocation criteria in Annex II to reflect reduced funding realities while maintaining growth objectives.  
ALDE highlights the need to accelerate permitting processes for critical infrastructure, aligning with the issue’s coherence goals and ALDE’s advocacy for streamlined EU governance.  
ALDE commends the focus on energy interconnectivity as effectively advancing regional stability and decarbonization, core pillars of ALDE’s energy policy framework.

SD strongly approves the accelerated authorization procedures and single-window mechanisms as crucial steps toward eliminating energy isolation between member states, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to integrated EU energy markets.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 to mandate biannual progress reports on cross-border infrastructure coordination, addressing persistent bottlenecks while fully endorsing the issue’s project eligibility criteria.  
SD approves the prioritization of renewable energy integration through Projects of Common Interest, which effectively advances SD’s 2022 Renewable Infrastructure Pact for decarbonized energy systems.  
SD emphasizes the need to pair the Connecting Europe Facility with dedicated project bonds to secure sustainable funding, reflecting SD’s manifesto call for crisis-responsive infrastructure investments.  
SD applauds the environmental safeguards in permitting processes as matching their Green New Deal principles, while urging stricter alignment with EU biodiversity targets in Annex II implementation.

GUE_NGL rejects the market-driven approach to energy infrastructure as absolutely disapproveing with their commitment to public ownership and universal service guarantees.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s reliance on liberalization, which their analysis shows exacerbates energy poverty by prioritizing corporate profits over affordable household access.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of GUE_NGL’s energy justice agenda, including binding mechanisms to prevent monopolistic concentration and worker rights erosion.  
GUE_NGL condemns the use of public funds to subsidize private energy conglomerates, a practice entrenched in the issue’s infrastructure financing model.  
This framework directly contradicts GUE_NGL’s demand for democratically controlled renewable energy systems that break dependence on profit-driven market actors.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0658) concerning EU transport infrastructure, addressing concerns over subsidiarity raised by the UK House of Commons and incorporating opinions from the Court of Justice, European Central Bank, Committee of the Regions, and parliamentary committees on industry, economic affairs, environment, consumer protection, transport, and regional development. The resolution formally adopted the Parliament’s first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for coherent infrastructure development and urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending significant amendments. It also mandated the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU objectives while respecting procedural and consultative inputs from key institutions.

title: Trans-European telecommunications networks: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on guidelines for trans European telecommunications networks and repealing Decision No 1336/97/EC
background: The European Commission proposed updated guidelines in 2011 and 2013 to modernize EU telecommunications infrastructure, addressing technological advancements and evolving connectivity needs since the 1997 framework. Budget revisions under the Connecting Europe Facility reduced funding allocations. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures for trans-European telecommunications networks to enhance digital infrastructure and interoperability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on advancing high-speed broadband infrastructure, aligning with its commitment to digital competitiveness and economic growth.  
EPP endorses the ambitious upgrade to 1 Gbps network speeds by 2020, recognizing this as essential for future-proofing Europe’s digital economy.  
EPP applauds the preservation of the Safer Internet program, urging sustained funding to protect children from harmful online content and expand digital literacy initiatives.  
EPP highlights the critical need for prioritized broadband deployment in rural and disadvantaged regions, proposing enhanced technical and financial measures to eliminate connectivity gaps.  
EPP emphasizes the importance of network prioritization mechanisms to safeguard emergency services and ensure uninterrupted quality for critical applications.

EFD supports the issue’s focus on cybersecurity in trans-European networks but advises amending Article 4 to explicitly mandate end-to-end encryption standards for all data transmissions.  
EFD highlights the need to safeguard security investments, proposing a clause in Section 3.2 prohibiting budget reductions from weakening critical infrastructure protections.  
EFD agrees with the interoperability goals but urges regular third-party security audits for projects of common interest, aligning with their 2023 manifesto’s emphasis on proactive cyber defense.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the Commission's top-down infrastructure approach as arbitrary and anti-competitive, contradicting principles of subsidiarity.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's lack of strategic coherence with prior digital initiatives like e-identification research programs.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to address wasteful spending patterns in EU-funded technology projects.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the proposal's compatibility with sustainable digital policy development goals outlined in Verts/ALE manifestos.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's inconsistency with grassroots network deployment models proven effective in member states.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s prioritization of cross-border digital public services and high-speed broadband infrastructure, aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to a unified digital single market that enhances mobility for citizens and businesses.  
SD applauds the emphasis on e-invoicing adoption as a transformative tool for economic efficiency, noting its potential to save €240 billion over six years, which perfectly aligns with SD’s economic modernization agenda.  
SD proposes enhancing the Connecting Europe Facility’s budget allocation for digital networks to address underfunding concerns, ensuring future-proof infrastructure while maintaining strong support for the regulation’s core objectives.  
SD emphasizes the need for robust interoperability frameworks for eHealth and eProcurement systems, urging amendments to Annex provisions to explicitly include these as critical trans-European public services.  
SD suggests exploring alternative funding mechanisms beyond structural funds to mitigate budget constraints, ensuring seamless cross-border connectivity without opposing the issue’s strategic vision.

ECR strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on broadband infrastructure as foundational to EU innovation and economic growth, aligning with ECR’s commitment to a competitive digital single market.  
ECR proposes enhancing consumer protection clauses in Article 9 to mandate transparent pricing and service quality standards, addressing challenges faced by Croatian citizens regarding telecom providers’ practices.  
ECR approves the funding mechanisms from the trilateral agreement, recognizing their necessity to achieve 100 Mbps connectivity targets and bridge gaps in underserved regions like Poland’s rural areas.  
ECR highlights the need to prioritize rural broadband deployment in implementation guidelines, ensuring inclusive access to match urban connectivity levels and eliminate regional disparities.  
ECR underscores that affordable internet access must remain a core metric of success, enabling the issue’s goals to directly benefit households and educational institutions across the EU.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's focus on directing public funds to supplement private telecom infrastructure in underserved regions, aligning with their commitment to territorial cohesion and combating rural depopulation.  
GUE_NGL advises modifying Article 2 to explicitly prioritize "zero-coverage areas" over percentage-based high-speed targets, ensuring subsidies address absolute connectivity gaps rather than urban duplication.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes amending Article 5 to include binding affordability requirements for subsidized networks, preventing price discrimination against low-income households and disabled users.  
GUE_NGL cautions against overreliance on market-driven deployment metrics, noting the issue’s current wording risks perpetuating urban-rural divides unless accompanied by granular accessibility mandates.  
GUE_NGL endorses provisions linking broadband access to job retention in remote areas but proposes adding specific funding mechanisms for local digital skills programs in recital 12.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the European Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0657) and its 2013 amended version (COM(2013)0329), which aimed to advance policy objectives under Article 172 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution integrated inputs from the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and parliamentary committees covering industry, environment, internal market, regional development, and culture. It formally adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, stressing the need for the Commission to uphold legislative coherence and consult Parliament anew if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, thereby safeguarding inter-institutional accountability and alignment with the original goals.

title: Connecting Europe Facility: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Connecting Europe Facility and repealing Regulations (EU) No 1316/2013 and (EU) No 283/2014
background: The European Union’s existing Connecting Europe Facility (2013-2014) governed cross-border infrastructure investments in transport, energy, and digital networks. Growing climate commitments, evolving technological demands, and post-2020 budget priorities necessitated regulatory updates to align with decarbonization goals and address transnational connectivity gaps. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised CEF framework focusing on transport, energy, digital infrastructure, and cross-border renewable energy cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's prioritization of cross-border transport and energy networks, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to EU cohesion through infrastructure integration.  
EPP approves the inclusion of regional airport funding and extended transport corridors to Ukraine as critical for economic growth in Central Europe, effectively advancing EPP's priority of market connectivity.  
EPP highlights an enhancement opportunity to amend Article 12 by allowing faster reallocation of unused CEF funds to avoid project delays, ensuring geographical balance without reducing overall Eastern European allocations.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on smart transport technologies like ERTMS, which matches EPP's 2023 manifesto goals for decarbonizing mobility systems.  
EPP emphasizes strict adherence to reciprocity in third-country procurement rules to protect EU industries while maintaining strong support for the issue's trade compliance framework.

EFDD firmly opposes the energy infrastructure provisions for cementing fossil fuel reliance until 2050, directly contradicting IPCC climate urgency.  
EFDD rejects wireless connectivity expansion due to unresolved electromagnetic health risks, violating the precautionary principle enshrined in EU treaties.  
EFDD condemns the issue's failure to prohibit fossil-aligned projects like gas pipelines, irreconcilable with decarbonization targets.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's negligence toward cumulative radiation exposure studies, endangering public health in digital infrastructure rollouts.  
EFDD denounces budget allocations for legacy energy systems as generational betrayal, prioritizing corporate interests over climate survival.

ENF opposes fundamentally the Connecting Europe Facility's focus on cross-border renewable energy cooperation, which overlooks the urgent need to allocate resources toward combating Islamic terrorism and securing national borders.  
ENF rejects the issue’s prioritization of decarbonization and digital connectivity projects, arguing it diverts critical funds from addressing existential security threats like radicalization within EU cities.  
The proposal’s transparency measures and public procurement criteria conflict with ENF’s principles by imposing bureaucratic burdens that hinder swift, security-focused infrastructure investments.  
ENF condemns the issue’s geographical budget balancing for digital networks as inconsistent with the party’s demand for immediate, targeted spending on counter-terrorism and border control.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the proposal's continued investment in gas pipelines and motorways, which directly contradicts the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C threshold and their climate neutrality mandate.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the failure to mandate 100% zero-emission transport infrastructure, rendering the issue incompatible with cross-border renewable energy transitions outlined in their climate strategy.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the omission of binding criteria to exclude fossil fuel projects, a critical oversight given the EU Commission’s stated climate-neutrality objectives.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the disregard for urgent Brexit-related transport solidarity measures, such as prioritized Ireland-continent connections, which the issue fails to address despite escalating no-deal risks.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the prioritization of highway expansions over low-carbon mobility systems for rural and suburban areas, undermining inclusive decarbonization efforts.

ALDE strongly approves the issue's emphasis on cross-border renewable energy cooperation and digital connectivity infrastructure as vital for advancing Europe's decarbonization agenda.  
ALDE proposes enhancing budget certainty by urging member states to prioritize cohesion fund transfers to ensure the CEF's 500 billion euro infrastructure needs are fully met.  
ALDE applauds the transparency measures in Articles 12-14, particularly real-time project data publication, which aligns with their manifesto commitments to accountable EU spending.  
ALDE recommends amending energy project eligibility criteria to phase out fossil fuel infrastructure investments, ensuring full alignment with the EU's 2050 climate neutrality targets.  
ALDE approves the geographically balanced allocation model for digital connectivity projects as a strategic tool to reduce regional disparities in technological readiness.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on cross-border renewable energy cooperation and decarbonization, aligning with their longstanding commitment to sustainable growth and climate action.  
SD approves the prioritization of socio-economically beneficial digital connectivity projects, particularly the inclusion of smart technologies and free public wireless access, which effectively advance equitable infrastructure development.  
SD proposes enhancing the digital connectivity provisions by extending 5G deployment to social hubs such as schools and hospitals, ensuring comprehensive continent-wide coverage beyond road corridors.  
SD applauds the increased co-financing rates for rail and cross-border projects, which strengthen economic cohesion and regional integration as outlined in the issue’s goals.  
SD emphasizes the importance of transparent budget allocations and real-time project data publication, which uphold accountability and align with their manifesto commitments to governance reform.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the failure to establish environmental and health standards against electromagnetic contamination, directly conflicting with their core principles of ecological precaution and public welfare.  
GUE_NGL opposes the inclusion of CO2-intensive energy technologies like liquefied natural gas, which starkly contradicts the issue’s decarbonization aims and perpetuates climate-harming infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of strengthened climate criteria for projects, rendering the mechanism incompatible with Paris Agreement targets they staunchly defend.  
GUE_NGL denounces continued funding for contested megaprojects such as the Lyon-Turin rail tunnel, opposing their social and environmental harm despite public resistance.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s "neutrality" principle as a deceptive loophole enabling fossil fuel lock-ins, irreconcilable with urgent zero-emission transitions they advocate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the establishment of a programme to develop and modernize trans-European networks in transport, energy, and digital sectors, emphasizing cross-border renewable energy cooperation, decarbonization, and synergies among these sectors to enhance competitiveness, economic cohesion, and sustainable growth. The resolution prioritizes projects of common interest in digital connectivity that deliver socio-economic benefits, including smart technologies (e.g., SESAR, ERTMS) and free, non-discriminatory wireless connectivity in public spaces, funded through geographically balanced budget allocations. Public procurement under the programme must prioritize cost-effectiveness alongside qualitative, social, and environmental criteria, with restrictions on tenders exceeding 50% third-country product value unless reciprocal market access agreements exist. Transparency measures include real-time publication of project data (e.g., impact assessments, beneficiaries) and mandatory two-step selection procedures for funding calls. Funding for free wireless connectivity is limited to public sector bodies, requires compliance with national laws, and prohibits duplication of existing services in the same area.

title: Energy efficiency: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/27/EU on energy efficiency
background: The European Union's existing energy efficiency targets under Directive 2012/27/EU, international commitments under the Paris Agreement, and the 2030 climate and energy framework necessitated policy alignment. Geopolitical shifts, including U.S. climate policy changes, heightened urgency to address energy security, competitiveness, and decarbonization. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the Energy Efficiency Directive to strengthen EU climate action and energy transition efforts.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly approves the governance framework's emphasis on investor certainty and market stability, perfectly aligning with their commitment to economic growth through sustainable energy transitions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's integration of bioenergy sustainability, advocating for member states' competence in forestry management as demonstrated in renewable energy provisions.  
EPP firmly approves the balanced approach to energy poverty measures, recognizing the mandatory national plans as crucial for social cohesion while maintaining fiscal responsibility.  
EPP strongly endorses the 35% renewable energy target as an ambitious yet achievable benchmark that drives innovation without overburdening industries.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's call for enhanced interconnections between member states, viewing this as essential for achieving energy union objectives and reducing import dependency.

EFDD rejects the issue’s decarbonization targets as economically harmful, citing studies showing green job subsidies destroy traditional employment and raise energy costs.  
EFDD totally rejects the omission of binding geothermal emission limits, condemning incentives for high-impact plants that bypass EU pollution accountability.  
EFDD rejects wind energy expansion for its ecological disruption, including threats to marine life and unsustainable corrosion costs in offshore projects.  
EFDD opposes the issue’s renewable energy targets as insufficiently ambitious, demanding binding national quotas and legislation to close geothermal regulatory gaps.  
EFDD criticizes the EU’s climate strategy as ineffective without global coordination, particularly after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris Agreement.

ENF rejects the proposed 40% energy efficiency target as economically unviable, citing Commission impact assessments showing €500 billion in additional costs that jeopardize industrial competitiveness.  
ENF opposes governance mechanisms imposing national energy plans as a federalist overreach violating subsidiarity, particularly rejecting Commission authority to sanction sovereign energy mix decisions.  
ENF condemns the exclusion of nuclear energy from decarbonization strategies as ideologically driven, contradicting cost-effective emission reduction pathways.  
ENF completely doubts with LNG import dependencies mandated by the issue, which increase consumer prices and carbon footprints compared to pragmatic Russian pipeline cooperation.  
ENF dismisses consumer behavior mandates as hypocritical given proponents' refusal to adopt personal sacrifices like reduced air travel or energy austerity measures.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally accepts the issue’s integration of binding decarbonization strategies, which perfectly align with the imperative to uphold the Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C threshold through uncompromised energy efficiency action.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the exclusion of conditional adjustment mechanisms, ensuring member states cannot evade binding renewable energy targets or dilute accountability under the Directive.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally accepts the issue’s rejection of first-generation agrofuels in transport, a critical step to halt deforestation and prioritize genuine renewables over false solutions like nuclear or fossil-derived alternatives.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for unconditional 35% renewable energy benchmarks, reflecting the urgency to phase out coal and nuclear power while accelerating solar and wind investments.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally accepts the issue’s emphasis on regional energy markets and grassroots innovation, which mirror the Greens’ vision for a just, collaborative transition to climate-neutral economies.

ALDE strongly agrees the governance framework's emphasis on long-term decarbonization strategies and investor certainty, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to market-driven energy transitions.  
ALDE approves binding national climate plans but proposes streamlining reporting timelines to enhance cross-border coordination without delaying implementation.  
ALDE strongly endorses prioritizing renewable energy systems over fossil dependencies, particularly praising provisions enabling frontrunner states to accelerate clean energy adoption.  
ALDE highlights the need to reinforce sustainable biomass criteria through national forestry laws rather than EU-wide bureaucracy as an enhancement opportunity.  
ALDE strongly backs monitoring mechanisms for Paris Agreement compliance, urging explicit alignment with innovation funding instruments in Article 7.

SD strongly promotes the binding 40% energy efficiency target as essential for aligning with Paris Agreement goals, emphasizing its potential to lift 35 million Europeans from energy poverty through building renovations and job creation. This aligns perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to social equity and climate justice.  

SD approves the exclusion of palm oil from renewable incentives, advocating for sustainable biomass criteria that prevent deforestation while maintaining forest-based climate solutions. The issue effectively advances SD's priority of balancing ecological preservation with clean energy transitions.  

SD endorses integrating energy poverty eradication into national climate plans, proposing enhanced monitoring frameworks to prioritize vulnerable households in renovation programs. This mirrors SD's 2023 manifesto focus on equitable energy transitions.  

SD highlights the need to strengthen regional grid interconnections to support renewable integration, suggesting accelerated infrastructure timelines to match decarbonization ambitions without opposing the issue's core principles.  

SD proposes refining primary energy factor calculations to ensure transparent tracking of efficiency gains across sectors, enhancing accountability while fully supporting the 40% target's implementation.

ECR rejects the binding 40% energy efficiency target as economically unfeasible, arguing it imposes unsustainable billion-euro burdens on citizens and businesses without cost-benefit analysis.  
ECR fully opposes the issue’s disregard for national sovereignty in energy policy, particularly its erosion of member states’ rights to determine their energy mix under Treaty Article 194.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s failure to address energy poverty risks, citing Greece’s forced privatization of public utilities and 35,000 electricity disconnections for vulnerable households as direct consequences.  
ECR condemns the unrealistic renewable energy targets for ignoring Commission impact assessments, warning that unsustainable biomass policies could destabilize EU competitiveness.  
ECR opposes the issue’s top-down governance model, stressing it exacerbates political tensions between member states and undermines subsidiarity in energy strategy design.

GUE/NGL conditionally agrees the governance framework but requests binding national targets for renewable energy to prevent member state complacency.  
GUE/NGL opposes the 12% transport sector target for relying on biofuels that exacerbate deforestation and carbon emissions, demanding amendment to exclude land-intensive energy sources.  
GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s vague definition of energy poverty in recitals, insisting on a legally binding formulation to protect vulnerable households.  
GUE/NGL highlights contradictions with public energy ownership principles, noting the proposal’s market-driven approach fails to ensure democratic control over strategic sectors.  
GUE/NGL demands deletion of linear decarbonization trajectories, citing their incompatibility with economic realities and physical constraints in smaller member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the 2016 Commission proposal (COM(2016)0761) concerning energy union governance, emphasizing alignment with EU climate and energy targets, including the 2030 framework and the Paris Agreement. It adopted amendments to strengthen transparency, member state accountability, and long-term decarbonization strategies, while integrating opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2017) and the European Committee of the Regions (July 2017). The resolution stressed the need for coherent national energy and climate plans, robust monitoring mechanisms, and enhanced regional cooperation. It called on the Commission to ensure consistency with EU treaties, subsidiarity, and proportionality principles, and to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantially amended. The Parliament’s Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety contributed to the final report (A8-0391/2017), which was forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments for further action.

title: Energy efficiency labelling: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting a framework for energy efficiency labelling and repealing Directive 2010/30/EU
background: The EU's energy efficiency labeling framework, established under Directive 2010/30/EU, faced challenges due to evolving product technologies, consumer confusion from proliferating "+" efficiency classes, and outdated digital compatibility. The European Commission proposed reforms in 2015 to modernize labeling standards. The Parliament will discuss revising energy labeling regulations to improve clarity, adaptability, and market transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the standardized A-G energy efficiency scale, which aligns perfectly with EPP's commitment to consumer clarity and market-driven innovation, as emphasized by Franc Bogovič and Vladimir Uruchev in simplifying labels for informed choices.  
EPP applauds the structured Working Plan under Article 11 for enhancing regulatory transparency, effectively advancing EPP's priority of traceable governance in delegated acts.  
EPP proposes streamlining the supplier database (Article 3(1)(d)) to reduce administrative burdens, urging cost-benefit reviews to ensure proportionality while maintaining compliance goals.  
EPP strongly endorses mandatory software updates under Article 6A, ensuring energy efficiency evolves with technological advancements as highlighted by Gunnar Hökmark’s business-driven development principles.  
EPP approves the strengthened stakeholder consultation in Article 10, which aligns with EPP’s longstanding advocacy for balanced policymaking through institutional dialogue.

ENF rejects the mandatory software updates in Article 6A as regulatory overreach inconsistent with ENF's principles of limiting state interference in technological development.  
ENF completely condemns with the expanded definitions in Article 2, arguing they introduce ambiguity contrary to ENF's demand for legislative clarity.  
ENF opposes the inclusion of second-hand products under Article 1, claiming it imposes unworkable compliance burdens on small businesses.  
ENF criticizes the stakeholder consultation requirements in Article 10 as bureaucratic delays masking ineffective governance.  
ENF rejects the supplier database alignment in Article 16 for failing to address cybersecurity risks inherent in centralized systems.

GREEN_EFA fully againsts the issue's failure to mandate EU-wide A-G energy labels by 2023, conflicting with their principle of urgent climate action and consumer transparency.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the inadequate provisions for a centralized product energy database in Article 3(1)(d), which overlooks critical needs for real-time consumer access to verified consumption metrics.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the exclusion of Tamburrano’s original requirements for dynamic software updates in Article 6A, creating loopholes in long-term energy efficiency compliance.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the 2030 timeline for label rescaling as inconsistent with their manifesto pledge to eliminate "energy class inflation" by 2025.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s erosion of binding ecodesign synergies under Article 11, undermining circular economy goals central to their platform.

ALDE absolutely advocates the issue’s harmonized energy labeling framework as a transformative step toward consumer transparency and market-driven innovation, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to simplifying EU regulations while advancing sustainability.  
ALDE applauds the mandatory software updates under Article 6A, which ensure enduring energy efficiency compliance and mirror ALDE’s 2023 priorities on adaptive, future-proof environmental governance.  
ALDE highlights the refined inclusion of second-hand products and structured stakeholder consultation in Articles 1 and 10 as critical to balancing market fairness with ecological accountability, a cornerstone of ALDE’s pro-competitive ethos.  
ALDE recognizes the simplified A-G rescaling as pivotal for restoring consumer trust post-Volkswagen, echoing its manifesto pledge to eradicate greenwashing through unambiguous, enforceable standards.  
ALDE urges accelerated implementation timelines to maximize emissions reductions, framing the issue’s 2030 targets as a foundation for even bolder climate action in line with ALDE’s advocacy for rapid decarbonization.

SD absolutely agrees the unified A-G energy efficiency scale, which perfectly aligns with their commitment to consumer clarity and informed purchasing decisions as championed by Martina Werner.  
SD perfectly aligns with provisions ensuring real-world compliance testing to prevent future "dieselgate" scenarios, advancing their priority of transparent environmental accountability emphasized by José Blanco López.  
SD absolutely agrees the centralized product database framework, effectively advancing market surveillance capabilities and harmonizing enforcement across member states as highlighted in the issue’s strengthened Article 10.  
SD perfectly aligns with the mandatory software update requirements under Article 6A, recognizing their critical role in maintaining long-term energy efficiency standards for evolving electronic products.  
SD absolutely agrees the issue’s structured Working Plan for delegated acts, which directly operationalizes their manifesto goal of regulatory predictability and stakeholder-inclusive policymaking.

ECR strongly promotes the reversion to A-G energy labels, aligning with their commitment to eliminating consumer confusion through transparent, standardized metrics.  
ECR approves the Article 11 Working Plan’s transparency measures, which advance their priority of reducing bureaucratic opacity in delegated acts.  
ECR endorses the ten-year rescaling framework in Article 10, emphasizing its alignment with their principles of regulatory certainty for industry and cost stability for consumers.  
ECR highlights the necessity of maintaining strict population thresholds for top energy classes (Article 6A) to preserve market-driven innovation while achieving efficiency gains.  
ECR proposes ensuring the supplier database (Article 3(1)(d)) remains narrowly focused on surveillance to avoid disproportionate administrative burdens on SMEs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised substantive amendments to the Commission’s proposal on energy-related products, including expanding Article 2 with six new definitions to clarify terms consistently used in the text. It introduced a new Article 6A mandating software updates for products with increasing electronic components to ensure ongoing energy efficiency compliance. The resolution addressed second-hand products under Article 1, refining their inclusion in the scope. Article 10 was strengthened to require the Commission to consult the Consultation Forum before decisions, enhancing stakeholder input. A structured Working Plan under Article 11 was established to transparently track delegated act projects and their progress. Adjustments to Article 16 aligned the entry into force of supplier database requirements (Article 3(1)(d)) with the amended text. Additional provisions focused on rescaling frequency, maintaining population thresholds for top energy classes, database upkeep, and standardized label affixing or display to improve consumer clarity and regulatory coherence.

title: Establishing Horizon Europe – laying down its rules for participation and dissemination: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, laying down its rules for participation and dissemination
background: The European Union’s Horizon Europe framework programme, succeeding Horizon 2020, emerged amid global R&D competition, disparities in member states’ innovation capacities, and commitments to climate action under the Paris Agreement. The Parliament will discuss the programme’s design, funding priorities, and alignment with EU strategic goals for research, innovation, and cross-border collaboration.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses Horizon Europe’s €120 billion budget proposal, aligning with its commitment to scientific excellence and global competitiveness while urging Member States to adopt Parliament’s ambitious funding level.  
EPP applauds the focus on climate action and SME innovation, proposing enhanced collaboration between agricultural researchers and Horizon Europe to address food security challenges without opposing the overall allocation structure.  
EPP endorses measures to bridge innovation gaps across regions, particularly the €4.8 billion for scientific excellence dissemination in underrepresented areas, which aligns with EPP’s priority of reducing brain drain and fostering inclusive growth.  
EPP emphasizes maintaining balance between foundational science and technological innovation, advising against disproportionate shifts in funding that could undermine long-term research capacity in line with EPP’s science-first principles.  
EPP strongly endorses synergies with defense and cohesion policies, highlighting how mission-driven research on AI and security aligns with EPP’s manifesto goals for citizen safety and technological sovereignty.

ENF strongly promotes the ambitious budget scaling of Horizon Europe, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to research-driven economic growth and global industrial leadership.  
ENF applauds the mission-oriented approach targeting decarbonization, which effectively advances Europe’s capacity to maintain its innovation edge while addressing climate priorities.  
ENF approves the emphasis on maximizing private-sector leverage through strategic R&D investments, reflecting their focus on high-impact returns for EU competitiveness.  
ENF proposes strengthening budget oversight mechanisms to ensure the Parliament’s proposed €120 billion target is fully realized, enhancing the program’s transformative scope.  
ENF strongly promotes the integration of SMEs as central innovation actors, consistent with their advocacy for empowering Europe’s entrepreneurial ecosystem.

GREEN_EFA fully accepts the issue’s commitment to allocating 35% of Horizon Europe’s budget to climate action, perfectly aligning with their demand for transformative climate funding to achieve net-zero emissions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of renewable energy and sustainable transport investments, which directly advance their vision of a climate-neutral EU as outlined in the Paris Agreement.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s synergy with EU climate neutrality legislation as a critical step to operationalize the bloc’s binding climate targets through research-driven innovation.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the €94 billion framework effectively channels resources toward climate-smart technologies, mirroring their call for systemic decarbonization across all research sectors.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s ethical governance model as instrumental in ensuring climate funds directly support frontline communities and SMEs in the green transition.

SD strongly promotes the mandatory allocation of 35% of Horizon Europe’s budget to climate action, aligning perfectly with SD’s climate justice priorities and the Paris Agreement commitments.  
SD applauds the reinstatement of the €2.5 billion SME innovation instrument, recognizing its proven success in driving market-ready solutions and regional economic growth for small businesses.  
SD strongly endorses the transversal integration of gender equality as an operational objective, ensuring inclusive participation and systemic equity for women researchers across all research clusters.  
SD proposes enhancing agricultural research funding within Horizon Europe to address CAP budget reductions, ensuring alignment with sustainable farming and food security goals without diverting resources from other critical clusters.  
SD strongly promotes the inclusion of social sciences and humanities, emphasizing their indispensable role in addressing cross-cutting societal challenges and grounding innovation in ethical frameworks.

ECR strongly upholds Horizon Europe's strategic allocation of €94 billion, recognizing its vital role in advancing EU-wide scientific excellence and global competitiveness.  
ECR applauds the issue's integration of support for coal-dependent regions, aligning with their advocacy for balanced energy transitions and regional economic resilience.  
ECR proposes enhancing clarity on the UK's participation status to maximize international collaboration opportunities, ensuring access to world-class research expertise.  
ECR approves the prioritization of SME funding and simplified administrative rules, which reflect their commitment to fostering innovation-driven economic growth.  
ECR emphasizes the need to maintain rigorous ethical standards and open science frameworks, reinforcing transparency in line with their accountability principles.

GUE_NGL absolutely challenges the issue's failure to explicitly exclude entities violating human rights from participation, contradicting their demand for binding ethical exclusions in third-country collaborations.  
GUE_NGL rejects the unresolved inclusion of the undefined "innovation principle," which aligns with corporate interests rather than public research priorities as advocated by the party.  
The proposal conflicts with GUE_NGL's anti-militarization stance by insufficiently prohibiting Horizon Europe funds from indirectly supporting defense-related research initiatives.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's inadequate safeguards for researchers' labor rights, particularly lacking enforceable provisions for parental leave protections across all member states.  
 While welcoming SME funding increases, GUE_NGL maintains structural biases persist against underrepresented regions' access to innovation resources.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2018)0435) concerning the establishment of Horizon Europe, the EU’s research and innovation framework for 2021–2027, emphasizing the allocation of €94 billion to bolster scientific excellence, global competitiveness, and societal challenges. It prioritized climate action, digital transformation, and health, mandating that 35% of the budget support climate-related objectives and 60% of funds target small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The resolution stressed synergies with other EU programs like cohesion policy and the European Defence Fund, while advocating for simplified participation rules, enhanced international collaboration, and inclusive access for underrepresented regions and researchers. It also underscored ethical standards, open science practices, and the integration of social sciences to address cross-cutting challenges, urging the Commission to ensure transparency and accountability in implementation.

title: Establishing the Connecting Europe Facility: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Connecting Europe Facility and repealing Regulations (EU) No 1316/2013 and (EU) No 283/2014
background: The EU's 2013-2020 Connecting Europe Facility supported trans-European transport, energy, and digital infrastructure, with evolving priorities for decarbonisation, cross-border connectivity, and renewable energy integration amid climate commitments. The Parliament will discuss establishing a renewed funding instrument to modernise interconnected networks across these sectors while addressing cohesion and transnational infrastructure gaps.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's prioritization of cross-border renewable energy cooperation as aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to territorial cohesion and decarbonization through trans-European networks.  
EPP applauds the mandate for socio-economically impactful digital connectivity projects, particularly the deployment of non-discriminatory wireless access in public spaces, which effectively advances EPP's priority of market integration and smart growth.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 9 to allow faster reallocation of unused CEF funds to eligible projects in Eastern Europe when member states underutilize allocations, ensuring no regional development delays while maintaining budgetary discipline.  
EPP strongly endorses the issue's transport corridor extensions to Ukraine and funding eligibility for regional airports, recognizing their strategic value for EU-Ukraine trade links and balanced regional development as highlighted in EPP's 2023 Eastern Partnership agenda.  
EPP approves the real-time project mapping requirements as critical for transparency, urging the Commission to implement interoperable data standards to maximize stakeholder accessibility without opposing the current implementation timeline.

EFDD rejects the allocation of funds to fossil fuel-based energy infrastructure as fundamentally contradicting their decarbonization principles and locking Europe into outdated energy models  
EFDD opposes the expansion of wireless connectivity infrastructure without precautionary health safeguards, citing unresolved risks from prolonged electromagnetic exposure  
EFDD absolutely condemns the omission of precautionary principle language in digital provisions, directly conflicting with their core policy framework for health protection  
EFDD condemns the issue's failure to prioritize long-term environmental sustainability over short-term infrastructure investments, violating intergenerational responsibility commitments  
EFDD highlights the schizophrenia between funding fossil-dependent projects and the EU's 2030/2050 climate targets as irreconcilable with their climate emergency stance

ENF rejects the issue's infrastructure priorities as dangerously disconnected from counter-terrorism needs raised in parliamentary debate  
ENF firmly condemns with allocating €0.3 billion to digital networks while ignoring funding for surveillance systems to track radicalized groups  
The proposal overlooks ENF's core demand to reorient EU budgets toward border security instead of "duplicative" wireless access points  
ENF opposes energy transition funding that fails to address warnings about 30,000 Islamist threats within EU cities  
 Despite technical approval of CEF mechanisms, ENF's overriding security focus deems entire proposal incompatible with public safety imperatives

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's continued funding for gas pipelines and motorway expansions, firmly disapproveing with the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C threshold and EU climate neutrality pledges.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Facility's structural failure to mandate exclusion criteria for fossil fuel infrastructure, enabling stranded assets incompatible with decarbonization timelines.  
The issue overlooks critical climate governance mechanisms by omitting binding alignment checks with the European Green Deal's 2030 emission reduction targets.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the geographical allocation model for perpetuating investments in carbon-intensive transport modes rather than prioritizing transnational renewable energy grids.  
This proposal is inconsistent with GREEN_EFA's demand for 100% zero-emission transport funding, particularly given the issue's silence on phasing out combustion-engine corridor projects.

ALDE strongly accepts the Connecting Europe Facility's centralized management model and its prioritization of cross-border renewable energy synergies, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to decarbonization and smart growth.  
ALDE proposes enhancing budget adequacy by reallocating cohesion funds to ensure the CEF meets its 500 billion euro infrastructure needs without opposing the issue's core financial structure.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on transparent project mapping and socio-economic criteria in funding awards, which effectively advance ALDE's priorities for market competitiveness and territorial cohesion.  
ALDE urges reallocating fossil fuel infrastructure investments toward renewable energy projects to fully align with the EU's climate neutrality goals, transforming current gas provisions into enhancement opportunities.  
ALDE approves mandating free wireless connectivity in public spaces as a critical step toward digital inclusion, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for equitable access to emerging technologies.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s prioritization of cross-border renewable energy cooperation and increased rail co-financing, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to territorial cohesion and decarbonized transport systems.  
SD applauds the inclusion of geographically balanced wireless connectivity funding, proposing to explicitly extend 5G deployment to social hubs like schools and hospitals to enhance digital inclusion.  
SD endorses the mandate for socio-economic benefit assessments in digital projects, which effectively advances SD’s priority of community-driven infrastructure development.  
SD strongly sanctions the transparency requirements for real-time project mapping, reinforcing SD’s longstanding advocacy for accountable EU fund allocation.  
SD approves the focus on renewable energy interconnections over gas investments, directly matching their 2023 climate manifesto goals for electrification and COP26 alignment.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's inclusion of fossil fuel infrastructure funding as fully rejecting with decarbonization commitments  
GUE_NGL opposes the absence of binding electromagnetic pollution standards in digital connectivity projects outlined in Article 4  
GUE_NGL condemns continued financial support for climate-damaging megaprojects like the Lyon-Turin tunnel despite supposed socio-economic benefit requirements  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to enforce Paris Agreement compliance through strengthened climate criteria for energy sector allocations  
GUE_NGL denounces the "technological neutrality" principle enabling CO2-intensive energy systems as contradictory to just transition goals

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to develop trans-European networks in transport, energy, and digital sectors, prioritizing cross-border renewable energy cooperation to enhance competitiveness, market access, smart growth, and territorial cohesion while advancing long-term decarbonization and sectoral synergies. The resolution mandates that projects of common interest in digital connectivity must demonstrate significant socio-economic benefits, prioritizing actions enabling free, non-discriminatory wireless connectivity in public spaces, funded through geographically balanced budget allocations. Contract awards under the program must prioritize cost-effectiveness, incorporating qualitative, social, and environmental criteria, and reject tenders with over 50% third-country products if reciprocal market access agreements are absent. Public sector bodies are eligible for funding to deploy local wireless access points, provided they avoid duplicating existing free services. The Commission is required to publish real-time project maps with implementation data and ensure transparent, two-step selection procedures for funding calls, emphasizing socio-economic drivers, digital service relevance, and community benefits.

title: Establishing the Digital Europe programme for the period 2021-2027: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Digital Europe programme for the period 2021-2027
background: The European Union faced fragmented digital infrastructure investments, lagging global competitors in supercomputing and AI capacities, with insufficient cybersecurity coordination and digital skills gaps. The Parliament will discuss establishing a 2021-2027 EU funding programme to enhance digital transformation through strategic technological investments and cross-border cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the establishment of the Digital Europe programme as a transformative step to position Europe at the forefront of global digital competitiveness, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to technological sovereignty and SME empowerment.  
EPP approves the strategic focus on high-performance computing, enabling European SMEs to leverage EU-based supercomputers and reduce costly dependencies on third-country infrastructure.  
EPP highlights the critical importance of cybersecurity and digital skills investments, which directly address workforce shortages and safeguard economic resilience in line with EPP’s innovation-driven agenda.  
EPP proposes strengthening the AI funding allocation and accelerating a unified industrial policy to enhance Europe’s position in the global AI race, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition.  
EPP applauds the programme’s emphasis on public sector digital transformation, ensuring equitable access to digital tools across member states and advancing EPP’s priority of inclusive technological progress.

EFDD rejects the issue's failure to mandate safeguards against digital technologies' psychological harms, absolutely disapproveing with their precautionary principle.  
EFDD opposes the omission of binding measures to address cognitive fragmentation in youth despite documented medical evidence cited in their amendments.  
EFDD condemns the issue's uncritical alignment with technological innovation goals while ignoring degradation of "psicosensorial equilibrium" as outlined in debate interventions.  
EFDD demands mandatory health impact assessments for all funded projects, a critical omission that invalidates the programme's consumer protection claims.  
EFDD highlights irreconcilable contradictions between the issue's cybersecurity priorities and its silence on neuromedical risks of chronic digital exposure.

SD strongly sanctions the Digital Europe programme’s focus on ethical AI development and cybersecurity infrastructure, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to citizen-centric technological governance.  
SD approves the mandatory geographic balance in innovation hub allocation, which advances SD’s priority of reducing regional disparities through inclusive digital transformation.  
SD proposes enhancing the budget allocation for advanced digital skills training to 12% of the total programme funds to address workforce readiness gaps while maintaining overall support.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to synergize this programme with Cohesion Funds, ensuring infrastructure parity across member states matches SD’s cohesion policy objectives.  
SD applauds the cross-border cybersecurity collaboration framework as directly reflecting their manifesto pledge to safeguard EU digital sovereignty.

ECR supports the Digital Europe programme's focus on enhancing EU competitiveness through digital infrastructure but advises exempting national digital investments from Stability Pact deficit calculations to enable greater public funding flexibility.  
ECR recommends expanding the programme's scope to include mandatory safeguards against digital exclusion, particularly for elderly populations and regions with limited connectivity access.  
ECR proposes amending cybersecurity provisions to prioritize centralized EU-level coordination for financial sector protections, noting fragmented national initiatives remain insufficient.  
ECR advises leveraging ECB bond-buying mechanisms to supplement programme funds, targeting corporations actively investing in digital transformation technologies.  
ECR stresses the need for clearer cross-border digital infrastructure benchmarks in the Connecting Europe Facility to address interoperability gaps hindering pan-European services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting a resolution that emphasizes strengthening EU digital and technological capabilities through key funding programs, including the Horizon Europe Programme for research and development of new technologies, the European Regional Development Funds (ERDF) for deploying digital solutions and cybersecurity measures, the Connecting Europe Facility for broadband network infrastructure, and the Single Market programme to ensure product safety in the digital economy, cybersecurity, and artificial intelligence. The resolution calls on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends its original proposal and underscores the need to align these programs with broader EU strategic goals, such as fostering innovation, enhancing digital infrastructure, and safeguarding consumer interests in emerging technologies.

title: Establishing the European Defence Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Defence Fund
